title: La maman et la putain.1973.HDTV.W13
description:
One of the most important French films of the 1970s, Jean EustacheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s marathon drama focuses on three twentysomething Parisians in a bizarre love triangle: Alexandre (Jean-Pierre LÃƒÂ©aud) is a seemingly unemployed narcissist involved with both a live-in girlfriend (Bernadette Lafont) and a Polish nurse (FranÃƒÂ§oise Lebrun) whom he picked up at a cafÃƒÂ© and with whom he begins a desultory affair. Clocking in at over 3 1/2 hours, the movie focuses less on plot than on the confused and ambivalent interrelations of these three lost souls. As such, it becomes a searing document of the aftermath of ParisÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s social and sexual revolutions of the Sixties, particularly the uprisings of May 1968. These characters know that they are supposed to be free and liberated, but they donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t quite know how to go about it, or how to make it work in practice, and their efforts donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t seem to make them any happier. In the guise of a plotless style seemingly borrowed from cinÃƒÂ©ma vÃƒÂ©ritÃƒÂ© documentaries, Eustache unfolds a critique of both the illusory liberations of his social moment and the dead-end heritage of his cinematic moment. By casting Jean-Pierre LÃƒÂ©aud, an icon of the French New Wave who first made his name as the star of FranÃƒÂ§ois TruffautÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pioneering The 400 Blows (1959), Eustache sets out to rewrite the conventions of a French New Wave that had changed from a revolutionary film movement into a formulaic mainstream style. Despite its deceptively rambling manner, the film effortlessly intertwines its charactersÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ psychological dilemmas with a portrait of its cultural moment with a revision of a wide swath of film history from TruffautÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Jules and Jim to Jean RenoirÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Rules of the Game to Ernst LubitschÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Design for Living. This experimental classic is not for all viewers, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s an unforgettable, and historically indispensable, experience for those who can stick with it.
